head.title: Oh, to Be an Alaskan in October

hedline.hl1: Oh, to Be an Alaskan in October

abstract.p: Alaska Permanent Fund distributes record annual dividend check of $1,963.86 to each of 585,800 eligible state residents; fund has benefited from stock-market boom in recent years, growing to just under $28 billion from $15 billion in 1995 (S)

block.p: October may have been a tough month for the stock market, but it was profitable, as usual, for Alaskans.

By now, every man, woman and child who has lived in the state for at least a calendar year should have received an annual dividend check from the Alaska Permanent Fund. This year, a record $1,963.86 was distributed to each of the 585,800 eligible residents.
October may have been a tough month for the stock market, but it was profitable, as usual, for Alaskans.

By now, every man, woman and child who has lived in the state for at least a calendar year should have received an annual dividend check from the Alaska Permanent Fund. This year, a record $1,963.86 was distributed to each of the 585,800 eligible residents.

The fund was set up about two decades ago as a way for Alaska to support itself after its oil fields run dry. Half of the fund's annual earnings are reinvested; the other half are distributed to Alaskans every October.

Like many other investors, the state fund has profited from the booming stock market of recent years, growing from nearly $15 billion in 1995 to just under $28 billion this year. Likewise, the annual dividend has grown rapidly -- in 1995, Alaskans received $990.30 each.
The annual windfall fuels a spending spree, which accounts for as much as 10 percent of annual spending in Alaska, according to state economists.

''One can attribute a lot of the growth in the Alaskan economy in the last decade to the growing dividend,'' Scott Goldsmith, an economics professor at the University of Alaska at Anchorage, said in a recent interview with The Associated Press.
